docs.lead_paragraph: AS a pot of split-pea soup simmered on the stove recently, Jennifer Christensen and her mother, Josephine, planned the feast they would whip up to celebrate Jennifer's impending 22nd birthday: stuffed shells, chicken cutlets, eggplant parmesan, cannoli cake. They are expecting quite a gathering at their house here: Jennifer's aunt and sister-in-law from Yorktown, her two uncles, her best friend and perhaps a cousin.

headline.main: As Obesity Runs in Families, So Does Surgery to Combat It

docs.abstract: Article on rise in number of families in Westchester County, NY, whose members are undergoing stomach-reduction, or bariatric, surgery; number of people undergoing bariatric surgery has risen from 63,100 nationwide three years ago to estimated 170,000 today, but rise is number of cases is dramatically higher in Westchester; photo (M)
docs.snippet: AS a pot of split-pea soup simmered on the stove recently, Jennifer Christensen and her mother, Josephine, planned the feast they would whip up to celebrate Jennifer's impending 22nd birthday: stuffed shells, chicken cutlets, eggplant parmesan,...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's budget for 2006 cuts spending for a wide range of public health programs, including several to protect the nation against bioterrorist attacks and to respond to medical emergencies, budget documents show. Faced with constraints on spending caused by record budget deficits and the demands of the war in Iraq, administration officials said on Friday that they had increased the budget for some health programs but cut many others, including some that address urgent health care needs.

headline.main: Bush Budget Calls for Cuts in Health Services

docs.abstract: Pres Bush's budget for 2006 cuts spending for wide range of public health programs, including several to protect nation against bioterrorist attacks and to respond to medical emergencies; cuts are part of attempt to control federal deficit, while increasing spending on priority programs; administration is proposing to increase Pentagon budget by 4.8 percent, to $419.3 billion; photo (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush's budget for 2006 cuts spending for a wide range of public health programs, including some designed to protect against bioterrorism attacks.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR; Eric Schmitt contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Taking the first step in an ambitious, if risky, strategy to create a biotechnology center, the city of Phoenix has completed work on a $46 million medical laboratory building dedicated to genetic research. Finished in December, the 170,000-square-foot laboratory stands on a 15-acre downtown area known as the Phoenix Biomedical Center at Copper Square. Although the official opening is not until March, two nonprofit research groups -- the Translational Genomics Research Institute, known as TGen, and the International Genomics Consortium -- have already moved into four floors that they leased before construction.

headline.main: Phoenix Moves to Put Itself on the Biotechnology Map

docs.abstract: City of Phoenix completes work on $46 million medical laboratory building dedicated to genetic research; 170,000-square-foot laboratory, finished in December, stands on 15-acre downtown area known as Phoenix Biomedical Center at Copper Square; nonprofit research groups Translational Genomics Research Institute and International Genomics Consortium have already moved into four floors that they leased before construction; lab's official opening is in March; another floor of six-story facility is to be occupied by National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, arm of National Institutes of Health, leaving only one full floor still to be leased; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Taking the first step in an ambitious, if risky, strategy to create a biotechnology center, Phoenix has built a $46 million medical laboratory building.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES

docs.lead_paragraph: Airborne, a dietary supplement that many people take to help prevent and treat the common cold, is getting a lot of buzz. ''This stuff works,'' a young woman told a stranger in a Times Square pharmacy as she reached for one of the last three packages.

headline.main: Keeping Colds at Bay. Or Maybe Not.

docs.abstract: Cold-prevention supplements, such as Airborne, have become popular despite lack of evidence showing that they have impact on common cold; Dr Eric Larson, Group Health, Seattle, internist, asserts that if documented cold prevention existed then everyone would know about it and doctors would be using it; Airborne contains many well-known vitamins, minerals and herbs often suggested for fighting colds, including vitamin C, zinc, echinacea and garlic; various cold fighting products described; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors say there is so far no evidence to demonstrate that a popular dietary supplement prevents the common cold.
